name.value: The Smurf Game Happy-time Picture Matching

item.description:
The Smurfs are busy having a wonderful time. Can you match up all your cards to their happy activities?

Source: box

This is a simple game (recommended for ages 4-8) of matching colours and symbols. Each player has a hand of five cards which they must match to the corresponding spaces on the game board.

Players spin a spinner to determine what colour card they can play and then attempt to match the symbol on their card to a space on the board. If they have no card of the appropriate colour they must draw from the deck.

The winner is the first to play all their cards.

A piece of cheese is put into the mouth of a battery-driven mouse. The mouse is then set loose on the floor and dashes through the room. The players represent cats and have to catch the mouse's tail with a small plastic sling. The first player to succeed in that gets the cheese. After nine rounds, the player with most points is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Similar to Maniac Mouse

Cuboid is a game of skill for two players, to be played with a set of NestorTiles. The colours of the tiles are significant, but the numbers are ignored.

Each player builds a creature (the Oid) by assembling 6 differently coloured tiles to make a cube.

The remaining 48 tiles are shuffled, and put together randomly to make a 7x7 board, with one gap in the centre.

Starting with the second player, each player puts their opponent's Oid on the board, in an orientation of their choice.

The game begins. In each turn, players perform the following actions, in order, for each Oid they have on the board:

Eating: if the colour on top of the Oid matches the colour of their tile, the Oid eats that tile.
 Movement: the Oid moves in any orthogonal direction, by (a) sliding over any number of adjacent empty spaces, then (b) rolling onto the first tile it encounters. Oids cannot move onto or past other Oids.

Breeding: if the player's Oids have eaten six tiles, they breed. Assemble a new Oid, and have the opponent place it on the board next to an adjacent Oid.

The game ends when no more moves are possible. The player with the most tiles, either as parts or in Oids, is the winner.

Cuboid is an entry in the 1st Nestortiles competition, here:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/580556/1st-nestortiles-game-design-contest-by-nestorgames

Source: author

item.description: Simple roll-and-move with three pawns each. You have to go through a maze and need cards to pass some spots. There are also spots to draw new cards. Two pawns on the same spot block the space. First player having all three pawns in the goal wins (goal has not to be reached exactely)

All pieces are magnets in a transperant covered plastic maze. On your turn you roll two dice and use a magnetic stick to move your pieces. There are holes with different values for the different players. When a piece is fallen in a hole it will be scored. Game end when one player has only two pieces left. 
You can "accidentally" move pieces of other players.

item.description:
Promotional game for BP Strato Motor Oil.
Roll and move racing game. You can pay extra money to roll more dice (20 for 3 dice, 50 for 4 dice)
Every player tries to get all 3 cars in first. You are out of the game if you cann not pay. 
With event cards.

Abstract strategy game. Each player has one piece in the center of the board. This piece can move 4 spaces. Goal is to move your own piece to a specific corner. 
There are also common pieces (can be moved by any player) movemen 1,2 or 3. If I move one of these pieces, it is blocked for the other players until I change this piece.

Roll and Move game similar to Mensch ärgere dich nicht (Ludo)
Each player has 4 money pawns in one color (green, red, yellow or blue). Each monkey has a differnt tails in one of the four colors (green, red, yellow, blue).
There are four starting spaces and the monkeys start at their matching tail color and the goal spaces are also color coded for the tails.
You throw not only by landing on another pawn but also by overtaking.
Banana spaces are safe. And two monkey of the same color on one space are blocking.
The best: The six is worth 12 points and you can reroll, but 3 "6" in a row: you loose all pawns to the start, but 4 "6" in a row safes and 5 rolls of a "6" in a row is winning the game immediately.

item.description:
Les batailles de St Albans (Battles of St Albans) is an introductory level tactical medieval wargame about War of the Roses.

The game includes one A4 map, 34 units and leaders counters and 10 markers.

The game covers the two battles of St Albans, fought on the same battlefield:
- First Battle of St Albans (May 22, 1455), Richard, Duke of York v. Edmund Beaufort, Duke of Somerset
- Second Battle of St Albans (February 17, 1461), Richard Neville, Earl of Warwick vs. Henry Beaufort, Duke of Somerset

item.description:
Overview

Guesstimates is a strategic guessing game for 2-4 players or teams, which focuses on making intelligent estimates. Your goal is to occupy as large an area as possible on the game board using the blocks that you receive as rewards for making accurate guesses. Blocks are available in three different lengths and the better your guess, the longer the block you receive. Questions belong to three categories: Market, Technology and Brainteaser.

Playing the Game 
Each round starts with the question category being determined by a roll of the die.

One of the players reads the question aloud and when all players understand the question, the timer is started and all players have 90 seconds to make educated guesses and estimate as good a guess as possible. The players’ answers must be recorded in the block before the 90 seconds is out.

0, 1, 2 or 3 points then are distributed

The players put their points out on the board according to the rules below. The player with the least number of playing squares covered with points places theirs first, followed by the player with the second smallest number of covered playing squares, and so on. If two players have the same number of covered playing squares, then the player who is next to read a question places their points first.

The turn then goes to the next player and a new round begins.

Distributing the points

A correct answer within ± 25% gives 2 points.

If the answer is further away than ± 25% but within the range (10 x correct answer) to (1 / 10 x correct answer), the player receives 1 point.

The player who comes closest to the correct answer receives +1 point regardless of whether any points are obtained as described above.

Placing the points and winning the game

When new points are placed on the game board, they must be positioned adjacent to a previously played point of the same color.

In addition to the points themselves, players also get points for empty playing squares contained within a border of their lines of points, so it is tactically advantageous to build outwards to the edge of the game board.

When any player has a point that cannot be placed on the board, the game is over. The number of playing squares contained within each players’ delimited fields is calculated and added to their number of covered playing fields – the player with the highest score wins.

item.description:
Taiwan Strait Crisis 1950 is a 2 players strategic-level board wargame that simulates the battles between People's Republic of China (PRC) and Republic of China (ROC) in 1950s which is so called "The First and the Second Taiwan Strait Crisis." Two players control the People Liberation Army (PLA), the National Government Army (NRA) in Taiwan and US 7th Fleet respectively.

There are 9 turns in a games and each turn represents one year. Each player spend operation points to activate his troops in one area to attack, move or do special operations alternatively in a turn. The PRC player must get 10 victory points to win the game.

Before each operation, player must roll a die to draw a event marker randomly. The event maker is the mission the player needs to accompolish in the following turns. After finish the mission, the PRC player can increase the victory points and the Taiwan player can decrease the victory points.

name.value: Roads to Moscow: Battles of Mozhaysk and Mtsensk, 1941

item.description:
Roads to Moscow: Battles of Mozhaysk and Mtsensk, 1941 is a two-player game depicting battles in the Soviet Union during the drive on Moscow in October 1941. The two separate battles shown in this game are named for the main objective city on each map, Mozhaysk to the west of Moscow, and Mtsensk to the south. Perhaps the most dramatic of the many desperate battles fought in front of Moscow, these two battles combined all the elements of the great struggle. The Germans have an excellent fighting machine but are short on fuel and time. They must capture their objectives on a tight schedule or snow and mud will end their offensive. The Soviets are down to the rearward remnants of their once immense armies. If the Soviets can avoid being encircled by the fast moving German forces, high quality reinforcements from the Far East may finally allow them to stop the German advance.

Historically, the Soviets stood fast at Mozhaysk, fighting heavily even on the old Napoleonic battlefield of Borodino. Like Napoleon, the Germans eventually took the field, but at great cost in time and manpower. Near Mtsensk Guderian’s Panzer spearhead advancing north from Orel was ambushed by the Soviets thereby disrupting the German timetable. This gave the Soviet 6th Guards Rifle Division time to dig-in on the heights above Mtsensk thereby barring the way to Tula and Moscow.
 Roads to Moscow uses the same mechanics found in the acclaimed Roads to Leningrad game, featuring a chit draw for activation of formations. Both players quickly learn how to use their motorized units effectively for overruns, combined arms, and movement of reserves. The game includes special rules for Soviet rocket artillery, NKVD, and self-propelled gun units, and fuel supply shortages, and much more, all without overwhelming play of the game.

Game Scale:
Turn: 12 hours
Hex: 1.4km (Mozhaysk ), 1.2km (Mtsensk)
Unit: Company to Battalion for most combat units, with Brigade & Division HQs

COMPONENTS
 Three counter sheets (528 5/8" counters)
 One 22" x 34" Mapsheet (front & back printed)
 4 Player Aid set-up cards
 1 Charts & Tables card
 Rule book
 Play book
 1 ten-sided die

DESIGNER: Vance von Borries
DEVELOPER: Mark Guttag
ART DIRECTOR: Rodger B. MacGowan
MAP & COUNTER ART: Charles Kibler

(source: GMT website)

item.description:
Description from the box and website:

The King has died without an Heir!!

Gather enough allies and power to claim the throne for yourself.

Will your reign be one of chivalry and bravery? Or one of diplomacy and deception? Will it be of prosperity and fertility or will the endless struggle throw the country into a devastating rebellion?

Time is against you as you join the chaotic era of the Rising Kings!


Rising Kings is a fun and entertaining cardgame for adults and kids age 12 years and up.

Each box contains 97 cards, a rulebook (English, Danish and German) and 15 overview cards (English, Danish and German).


Gameplay:
Players draw cards from a shared playdeck and play cards from their hands. Every card is put into play and has an effect when played. A few cards have an ongoing effect - like the Fortress and the Cityguard.

There are three types of cards: characters, buildings and rebellions. Each player can play one character card, one building card and any number of rebellion cards on his turn.

When the last card is drawn from the playdeck the game ends. Each player is awarded points for buldings and characters he controls, and the one with the most points becomes the King.
It is possible to get bonus points for being the one with the most characters or buildings of each type.

Examples of card effects:
The thief allows you to steal two cards from an opponent's hand, while the saboteur allows you to destroy a building controlled by another player.
The Inn allows you to play an extra character, while the University lets you retrain and replay one of your existing characters.
The Rebellion disables the effect of a Fortress or Cityguard.

Roll and move on a round board with 8 rings and 12 segments. Players start in the center and can move inwards, outwards or along the rings with one die roll.
You try to get all 6 different fruit cards. On a space with a fruit you roll 5 dice and try to get as many dice from this fruit. One reroll is free. All other rerolls cost money.
5 of a kind gives the fruit card matching. 3,4 and 5 of a kind gives money.
In the outer ring you get a fruit card only with 4 of a kind.

From the back of the box: 
The luck of a dice roll with the strategy of a challenge!
Build enough sets of 4 and win.

The game's fast and furious so the cards lay on the table. When you see the cards you need, you're in luck - SHAKE'M & TAKE'M. But watch it! Your opponent might be luckier. Make another challenge. Shake 'm and OOPS! You lost. Next player.

There's plenty of action and risk when you SHAKE'M & TAKE'M. Cards go from player to player, back and forth. Dice roll with each challenge. And wild cards add to the fun as part of the strategy.

Players are attempting to acquire a number of sets of 4 cards each by challenging other players to a dice roll off. Players set down their hands face up in front of everyone. On your turn, you may challenge a player for some of their cards. You both roll a die and the higher roll wins the cards.

Junishi is an abstract strategy game inspired by the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. (Each player controls 6 of the 12 animals.)

The object of Junishi is to move one of your 6 animals into your opponents Gate, which is located at the opposite end of the board, in between your opponents Spawn Areas.

Players begin at either end of a board comprised of 19 circles arranged in a hexagonal pattern. 
 At the start of the game there are not any pieces on the board. Any pieces that a player wishes to use must be "spawned" in one of the Spawn Circles on that players side of the board. 
 Players may move the pieces that they already have on the board either by moving them into adjacent circles or by jumping over friendly pieces.
 Players also may use their animals to capture their opponents animals by jumping over them.

Junishi is a simple and fast paced abstract strategy game that is easy to learn and usually plays in under 20 minutes. It comes in a little cloth bag that also serves as the game board
and it can be carried in any pocket that is big enough to hold a pack of gum.

Junishi is a complete game that can be expanded by combining it with its sister games Zodiakos, 12 Moons, and Neteru.

(source : the publisher)
 Integrates with:

 12 Moons





 Zodiakos



 Neteru

In this Yahtzee-like dice game, players get to throw the five dice up to three times on their turn while attempting to make high-scoring sets, whether of animals, flags, or something else; many versions of this game have been released, and the symbols matter only for what you check off, not for a point value since each symbol is worth 1. Choose carefully which lines to score as each line can be scored only once! If all the possible choices for a roll have been filled, then you must score zero points on another line of your choice.

If you score 18 or more points on the upper half of the score sheet, then you receive 10 bonus points. (Note that unlike Yahtzee, each symbol is worth only one point; note also that in the lower section, each line has a specific scoring combination, e.g. three elephants score only with two bears, not with a two of something else. Roll five identical items, and you get a 10-point bonus. Whoever has the highest score when all the score sheets are filled wins!

item.description:
From the publisher:
Flakk - kapphlaupið að forna hliðinu is an exciting, non-violent Icelandic boardgame with fantasy theme where 2-6 players race to victory. The first player to get to the end wins. The game is for 10 years and older.

To begin each player chooses one of twelve characters, either a boy or a girl. Each character has it's special talent cards which the player uses in the game. Players move around the board using two dice and draw event, treasure or puzzle card according to the space they land on.

item.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Worms, in Germany.

item.description:
Simple roll and move train game. The players go around a train track. When they reach fields in front of a building, they have to perform a task in order to be able to proceed next turn (imitate an animal, sing a song, etc). When they stop on a tunnel field, they lose a turn as well.

This simple children's game was published in Geo mini magazine 2/2010.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Yaniv is an Israeli card game, played with a standard deck of cards.

Players attempt to be the first to decrease the value of the cards in their hand to below a designated number by discarding sets of matching cards. The first person to achieve this (known as "calling Yaniv") causes all other players to score a penalty based on their remaining cards. However, if another player reaches an equal or lower score at the same time, the player who calls Yaniv instead receives a hefty penalty.

link.value: Card Games: Draw and Discard Games

item.description:
The game itself is remarkably simple. As many as six people can play and learn at the same time. Players select a part of the world represented on one of six printed boards: Europe, North and Central America, South America, Asia, Africa and Oceania, which represents Australia, New Zealand and New Guinea.

Each player then attempts to collect all 20 playing cards related to his or her respective corner of the world by correctly answering questions about various towns, mountains and rivers.

Oceania’s 20 chromolithographic cards, for example, include questions and illustrations about cities such as Brisbane, Melbourne and Sydney, as well as various individuals and fauna such as Captain James Cook, kangaroos, echidnas, cassowaries and the Aborigines of Papua, New Guinea.

Cards from other continents include illustrations such as a herring fishery off the coast of Norway, the Suez Canal, the construction of the 1893 Chicago World’s Fair exhibition and a portrait of Christopher Columbus.

The game cards, boards and instructions are written in French, allowing Francophiles the opportunity to test their language skills.

From: USC Special Collections (University of Southern California)

http://uscnews.usc.edu/university/fun_and_learning_games.html

item.description:
A standard version of monopoly based on the classic London board - Park Lane and Mayfair - but in a small, small box. A portable version of Monopoly, with tiny components.

The cards and money are a bit fiddly, but this is a proper and complete version of Monopoly

This is a fast-playing stripped down version of the classic boardgame, Clue. Basically it is the question portion of the game made with a specific set of cards used as the notepad. The detail list of cards varies from the original and the design is in line with the up to date style of nowadays.

Play your cards right and you will solve it in no time.

Ask question about the Clue characters weapons and locations on your cards to work out who did it, with what and where.

As you expect, the first detective to solve the crime wins. It’s all the fun and intrigue of Clue, in minutes. Special 2 player game for top detectives!

This is not Clue Suspects, which is Outside the Scope of BGG

item.description:
Records of Three Kingdoms 190-280 is a 2-3 players strategic-level wargame that simulates historical battles during the Three Kingdoms period in ancient China. Players control the Cao Wei (æ›¹é­), Shu Han (èœ€æ¼¢) and Sun Wu (å­«å³) army respecitvely.

In the beginning of each turn, each player hires 2-3 generals and military counselors with corresponding soldiers. Each player can activate their generals and military counselors in one area to move, attack, remove, canvass, or cultivate. After each turn, they can produce food and soldiers from controlling areas. And some of their leaders might die in the next turn. You need to control the risk in every 5-10 years. Player who gets more victory points in the last turn of each scenario wins the game.

There are two scenarios in this game including the "Heroes Race for Power 194-220" (6 turns) and "The Rise of Three Kingdoms 223-280" (6 turns) and you can also combine the two scenarios to play the complete war of Three Kingdoms.

The components includes one 22*34 inches map and 180 5/8 inch die-cut counters.

link.value: Records of Three Kingdoms 190-280: Guandong Coalition

item.description:
Verbàlia, el joc is a collection of 50 word and language games (maybe 49, maybe 51, up to the players to discover) in Catalan. The games are all playable with the material included, and range from simple word formation games to complex sentence-forming games. There are games using letters and games using syllables; there are games to play solitaire and games to play with large groups; there are reflexive games and skill games; there are fast and crazy games and long and quiet games; there are party-oriented games and competitive and more strategic games, even a letter-based Texas hold'em. A treasure trove of games for word and language lovers!

Contents:
- 3 game boards
- 200 letter tokens
- 136 syllable tokens
- 120 wooden markers in various colours
- 4 notebooks
- 4 pencils
- 2 cloth bags
- The rulebook for the 50 games

Note that the distribution of letters and syllables is based on their relative abundance in Catalan and thus it is not playable with other languages. A Spanish edition is expected for Spring 2011.

item.description: Cheddar Challenge is an abstract game of strategy and skill similar to Chess. Imagine simplified Klingon Chess. Each player has three categories of wedges. Sharp Cheddar, Medium Cheddar and Mild Cheddar. There are specific sizes, numbers of, movements and strengths for each category of wedge. Each category of piece has unique movement and strength. (For example the Mild Cheddar has the greatest number of pieces.) The goal of the game is to win by capturing all wedges comprising one of your opponent's three categories of cheddar. A player will lose if they lose one of their categories. The game is played on a rhombus shaped game board made up of triangluar cells. The theme is fun because its based on cheese and the shapes of cheese wedges. And its much easier to learn and less complicated than Chess or Klingon Chess and can be a great introduction to those games later on.
Another of the many Monopoly games. This one from Alexandria, Indiana put out by the Alexandria Jaycees. Developed by the THETA TAU Sorority as a fund raising device.

Pacal, king of the Maya city Palenque, is trying to control all of the Yucatan's resources. As kings of other cities, his opponents have their own ideas. By using your influence to control resources in Kingdoms across the Yucatan, you can establish yourself as the greatest king of the Maya. Build Temples. Alter borders. Control resources.

During the game, players represent the kings who oppose Pacal and use the ten different resource cards and spend action points to expand their empires, dominate the 14 Yucatan kingdoms through their control markers, exchange the opponents control markers, reserve control markers and/or build Temples, scoring every time a Score Card is played by any player.

The player who has amassed the greatest amount of control over the Yucatan Peninsula in each of the scoring rounds is the winner.

item.description:
UNAUTHORIZED PRODUCTION

 
 
 The information that BGG has on this item indicates that Trek to Zion is a non-authorized version of Ticket to Ride. According to Days of Wonder, Pioneer Plus does not have license to produce this game, thus it is set apart from the official entry of Ticket to Ride.

 


Circle the wagons and gather your friends and family for this exciting new board game! Build the most wagon trains and travel across the United States, visiting the same cities and forts that the pioneers passed in the 1850s. Along the way, set up temples and establish Zion in the crossroads of the West. Whoever blazes the most trails and completes the most treks wins!

This game is pioneer themed clone of Ticket to Ride. It adds a new mechanic of "Temple Blessings" and a new map (of the US), but the rest of the mechanics are the same. Instead of claiming track and placing trains you claim a trail and place covered wagons. Instead of train cards, you have provision cards (Corn, Wheat, Horseshoes, etc.)

name.value: Auto Magnetic Pin Spotter Bowling Game

item.description:
This game comes from Irwin Co. and is circa 1968.

A regular bowling game that features a reset device so that you do not have to reset the pins yourself. You simply press down on the reset mechanism and the pins are ready for the next frame.

Godzilla: Stomp! is a fast-paced card game of monster-induced city destruction. The game is played in a series of rounds. During each round, several buildings will be revealed, and players will simultaneously choose their attack strength to destroy one or more buildings for the round. Play continues for six rounds, at which point players add up their scores. The highest score wins.

Contains:


 42 Building Cards
 30 Monster Attack Cards


From the back of the box:

Godzilla, the King of the Monsters, is on the loose again, along with four other Kaiju: Mothra, Mechagodzilla, Battra, & Destoroyah! Together they compete to demolish the most buildings in the city, by sparring it out or going into a full-out RAMPAGE!

There's nowhere to hide in this Kaiju free-for-all!

link.value: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

item.description:
Two players or two teams race to tie the knots pictured on the Knot So Fast challenge cards. After each match, the winners tug a rope in the card holder toward their side. The Knot So Fast Game features 40 knot challenge cards with a little knotty history, a tug of war score keeper, 4 colored ropes and 2 rings. Knot tying is a great skill to master at any age, and with the Knot So Fast Game from ThinkFun, younger players will also be improving their spatial reasoning and manual dexterity! Kids can practice their knots solo or play with 2 or more players, with the Knot So Fast Game!

This is a game about knots. Each player has a piece of rope. Each round, a knot is shown, and each player has to make that knot. When the first player finishes his knot, he announces this, and the other players receive 30 seconds to finish theirs. Then, the finished knots score points.

The first player to reach eight points wins the game. (Or, in the team game, the first team to achieve a sufficiently large lead wins.)

The name of the game comes from ELective SEstio. This is a C-section for the birth of a child without any medical reasons.

This game is published by the association of midwives as an educational tool against the elective sectio.

First you need to become pregnant so you have to draw a pregnancy card. Then you have to collect different cards for a "normal" birth.

There are several aims of the game mentioned. They are to be interpreted.

First player with a birth wins. Players with the most births win.
Avoid the ELSE card. Last player with ELSE card loses. (This aim is like in Old Maid [Schwarzer Peter])

The game designer confirmed all aims being valid.

48 square tiles (16 different cards 3 each) are shuffled and every player get 3 in the hand. Starting player put one card on the table and draw one card to have 3 hand-cards.

On your turn you lay a matching tile. Each tile has a triangle in one of the four colors and a triangle with a number 0,1,2 or 3 of dots.

When you finish on 4-tile square you count the dots on the 4 tiles.

After your turn you draw up to 3 cards

End: all cards are played. Player with the most points wins.

Special rule: You can put one tile in front of you if this impossible to lay it. (even if you have a matching tile in your hand) You can use this tile(s) in the following turn(s)

A GAME MADE OF STARS

Astrology: A way for people to understand the ways of the universe with the help of the stars.

Astrologica is a game in which you can alter Dominant Zodiacs and Zodiac Houses along with the Zodiac Elements. 
 The three most important Aspects in Astrology, the Zodiacs, Elements and the Zodiac sky, are yours to arrange and shift.

Players in Astrologica are like Astrologists, argue about the differences astrology has been through over the years. Many cards of the game show that change, from traditional to modern astrology. One of the main reasons, was the discovery of new planets. Until recently, Astrologists weren’t aware of the existence of the planets in the far reaches of our solar system. Due to the discovery of Neptune, Uranus, Pluto and the consolidation of the Sun centered planetary system, astrology had to change. New ruling planets were established for the Zodiac Signs, Houses were shifted and the characteristics of each sign changed in order to be aligned with the new form of our solar system.

Most of the cards of Astrologica feature these changes, as each player makes the changes available through modern and traditional sign characteristics.

In few words...

Cards help you gain extra points, while creating row of cards 
with the Proper Signs and Elements might grant you victory at the endgame.

As for the players, well, they try to put the Zodiacs in order along with the Elements.

The stars were always there. Our way of observing them through astrology changed, as we discover more and more of the universe we live in. An easy, competitive game destined for 2-5 players. Enjoy Astrologica by playing and learning of, the universe’s beauty combined with our imagination.

item.description:
A self published card game similar to UNO. In the deck there are only special cards. +/- shows the next player how many cards to draw (- is only for mathematical if there is already a positive number) if you can not play.
There is also a skip card. Terpentin cards are wild and stop the drawing of cards.

Translation: Cake-Fight.

Partnership trick-taking game with four suits:
yellow and red cake with numbers
yellow and red flour

You have to follow suit. In the number suit, highest number wins. In the unnumbered suits, tha last card followed suit wins the trick.

Card game in an "old time game" edition. Similar to Phase 10, but you have 13 phases:
1. 2 sets of 3
2. 1 tun of 4 and 1 set of 3
3. 3 sets of 3
4. 1 run of 5 and 1 set of 4
5. 2 runs of 4 and 1 set of 4
6. 1 run of 6 and 1 set of 5
7. 3 sets of 4
8. 4 sets of 3
9. 2 sets of 6
10. 1 run of 7 and 1 set of 5
11. 1 run of 8 and 1 set of 4
12. 1 run of 10
13. 1 set of 10

On your turn you take a card from the stock or the discard. If you have all your card for the actual phase you can lay them out. If one person gets rid of all hand cards the round ends. "2"s are wild cards.

A fan of horror movies or slasher films? This free print and play is your chance to see how you measure up to the classic greats. Are you the next Jason? Or will the cops end your reign of terror before it begins?

With victims that can fight back, potential news media alerting even more cops to you, and house weapons that can either help or harm you, things won't be as simple as you think.

Gameplay:

Players will use a deck of cards for the game board, and dice and the rules to get things done. Options include cutting lights off in homes, cutting phone lines, trying to fight and kill the victims, as in any slasher film. Of course, when that doesn't go to plan, then you need to decide how to deal with the police, potential survivor types, and other issues. Will you spend a turn rolling to pick up a weapon to help you kill? Or try to rush in and dispatch foes? It's all up to you. This game allows for quite a bit of choice.

Also included are Evil Points, which you earn, and can use to pull off the sorts of narrow escapes, and horror movie classics like escaping unscathed from gunfire.

Lastly, like any good slasher, on a certain roll, you have rage. This unleashes the true horror of your character. You get to create your own within the rules and see how well, and how long you can survive.

-SLASHER KILLER CUT-

This edition is the culmination of 8 years of this game existing, trial and error, pruning rules, and basically gutting my own creation to rewrite it in a much clearer, more concise way. Along with new rules that streamline the game into a faster experience, with more to do. 2 player variants now also included in the rules, along with an Official Character Sheet and Tokens.

Ground breaking new Football (Soccer) based trivia board game to play with all the family.
All the action of the real game even the referee. Pick your team and formation then test your knowledge to become a Football Legend.

A football pitch board and 1 soccer ball as marker, use your special cards and the right answers to move the ball towards to the goal; penalty cards, shoot cards ...referees ...yellow and red cards are adding a touch of realistic match to the game.

Playing wisely your cards and a good knowledge of football soccer history is the key to win the game.

Promotional game for Starman (Starman is one the largest provider of cable-TV and internet services in Estonia)

There are 3 different paths in gameboard (cable-TV,internet & phone services) and the objective is move 3 pawns at the end of all paths first.

Contents:

 Gameboard
 4x4 pawns
 1 die

As a give-away in the seventies, private customers of the insurance company DEVK received a free copy of the game "Der Ferien Express" (the holiday express), probably as a summer gift for the kids.

It is a simple Roll and Move game, with a gambling component.
Players have to supply their own player-tokens, coins, and a die. Only the board game field was given away.

Players roll a die which indicates how far they are allowed to move down the 42 field track trough Europe. If he lands in a black city (Copenhagen, Cadiz, Bern, Athens) the player has to pause for a round and has to pay a coin into the pot (as a hotel fee). If the player lands on a red City (Berlin, London, Paris, Madrid, Venice) he has to pause for a round, but has the chance to take a shortcut when rolling a one on a D6. If he is allowed to take the short cut (express line) he must pay two coins into the pot.

The first player who is back in Berlin receives half the pot, the second and third divide the rest.

Bag-O-Loot is a new card game that mixes elements of Rummy, Poker, and Go-Fish. Its design is unique in that it has a truly broad appeal to all age groups. It's simple to learn and kids love the idea of stealing cards from each other. At the same time, there is room for many different strategies that makes it appealing for adults to play. Add to this the bluffing element and you watch emotions come into the game as the interaction between players gets heated up.

Adults love to play the game with other adults, kids like to play it with other kids, and as a family, you can mix the age groups and everyone has a great time. When you finish a game, you are always wanting to play again.

According to publisher: Bag-O-Loot combines simplicity, strategy, socialization, luck, skill, bluffing and emotions into one exciting game that never gets boring and always has you coming back for more.

Players create sets of matching cards called collections. During their turn, a player can build a collection, steal collections from another player and finally create a Bag-O-Loot to close the collection out.

But watch out, the last card of the Bag-O-Loot could be a bluff.

item.description:
Who'd You Rather - The Ultimate Adult Party Game

In this game you attempt to be the first player to reach $1 Million by performing risque activities or by betting on the sexual preferences of other players in the following categories (as taken from the rules):

1. Pics - Some are hot, some are not - but you must choose one!
2. Celebs: This category compares two well-known celebrities.
3. Turn Ons/Turn Offs: This category is all about the things that might get you excited...or disgusted!
4. Down and Dirty: This category lets it all out. This is where other find out what you're really about - between the sheets, that is.
5. Anything Goes: This is the action category. You'll get to see people do things you never really thought they would do.

Each turn, The active player spins to see which category they must follow. They will then be asked to perform the action required to earn cash, or select their preference of two options (A or B) presented. They choose between A or B and place their answer card face-down in front of them. All other players also place an answer card in front of themselves with the answer they think the active player chose. Bets may be placed on answers to increase the money earned by a correct guess. The active player must reveal their answer and explain themselves. All correct players earn $50K plus whatever they bet. Incorrect players lose any money they wagered.

The game includes different pics/question card sets for people who prefer men and people who prefer women.

The game consists of a special die and a set of tiles. These depict things that dogs do (sniff, pee, run, etc.). In the basic game, the children take turns picking up a card and acting out the action. Then they can keep the tile. At the end of the game, the player with most different card colors is the winner.

In a competitive variant, the players take turns rolling the die. A player rolling a dog symbol can pick up cards and act out the pictures and keep the tiles until another player rolls the dog symbol. The player with most tiles at the end of the game is the winner.

(user summary by HilkMAN)

Card game where the player with the fastest reaction wins.

In the game there are 12 different "pairs" like: cow --> milk or hen --> egg. The first cards ist called start, the second gift (from god). Every player has a set of 12 gift card oppen in front of him. Now 1 start card is turned over an all players (wihtout the player turn over), try to find the matching gift card first to win the start card. After all 36 start card are played, the player with the most card earned wins.

name.value: Kommissar Rex: Wer stahl den Kohinoor?

item.description:
Row of four cards (A,B,C and D) should be built in the center of the table. On your turn you can play one of your 6 handcards. Start a row with an A or build on en existing row. On the card there are colored lines. A card can only be added if it has the same color as the last card of the row.
There are also jokers.
The player laying a D card gets the row as points and a player who can exchange a joker get the point for the exchanged card.

This is branded with the sheperd dog "Rex" from the TV show "Kommissar Rex"

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Five dice with letters are rolled. Now every player tries to build a word only with thes five letter, bur can use the five letters as often as they wish. The player rolled can use one joker letter.

Write down your word an put it in the game box. If all players but one wrote down a word the words will be scored. Each word is one point per letter plus a bonus for beeing fast.

A memory game. One player has the green knights, the other the blue knights. In your turn you first have to turn over a knight in your color. If not just turn hide the card and next player's turn. If you find your knight, you turn over cards as long as you find a dragon. Then a fight will happen. You roll dice for your knight and the other player for the dragon. For a killed dragon you get a treasure.

This game is limited to 100 copies.

A two player abstract game played on a 7 by 9 array of hexes. Each player has four pegs of his colour on the specified starting hexes. On his turn a player may move any one of his pegs any distance in a straight line but may not jump any other peg. The object of the game is to be the first to get all four pegs of your colour in a straight line. They do not have to be adjacent but there must be no opponent pegs between them.

Four different letters games can be played with the components included in the box:

1) Letter puzzle - longest possible word (Deal 9 letters onto table and all players use these letters to find the longest possible word. Players get 1 point for every letter in their word.)

2) Word builder - create as many words as possible using 3 random letters (Deal 3 letters onto table and players have 1 minute to create as many words as possible containing these letters. Players get 1 point for ever unique word they come up with.)

3) Word paths - search for words in a four by four grid (Create a random 4 by 4 grid of letters and players then find as many words as possible in the grid, similar to Boggle. Players gain 1 point for each unique word they find.)

4) Word crossing - use as many letters to make a crossword layout (Players are dealt 21 letters and have 5 minutes to create a crossword grid using these letters. Each player scores as many points as letters they use.)

This is a very strange card game. In the deck are 8 cards of this values: +1,+2,+3,+4,-2,-3.
Shuffle the deck an everybody gets 4 cards. Turn over the deck and do what the card says. If it is a positive card you as many cards from this deck. If it is a negative card you discard that number to the discard pile and add the negative card. When the deck runs out turn over the discard pile and go on. When all card are in the players hands, all positive cards count negative and the negative cards count zero.
Super Mario Bros branded card game. A mixture of rummy and canasta. You have to collect set and straits to get points. There are also some special cards.

Super Marion Bros. branded card game. On the cards there are Monster in different numbers. All players turn over one card from their own deck at the same time. If there are 6 or more monsters of the same kind, you have to slam pn the table to get all open cards. If you run out of cards you are out.

Based on the long-running Saturday night sketch comedy show, this board game has the players break up into teams to collect cards, won by completing a series of challenges based on various aspects of the television show. The challenges include trivia questions and impersonations of cast members, and are categorized by the "era" of Saturday Night Live they are drawn from.

The smallest memory game ever. There are three discs, each with a different color underneath: blue, yellow or red.
You roll a die (blue, blue, yellow, yellow, red, red).
You show the disc with this color and put the disc somewhere back on the table. If you choose the wrong one you have lost.
Surprisingly someone will make a mistake. Should be played really fast.

An England Football edition of UNO with 112 custom cards featuring England players. In addition to the normal UNO cards, there is the "Goal" card which allows players to swap a card with another player.

The board constist of two long rectangles forming a "X" and an "U". On your turn you add a piece in your color at the end of the "X" or the "U" or the cente of the "U". When all spaces are filled you get a point for each majority of the rectangles of the "X" and the "U". Most points win.

The board is a square seperated by othogonal lines with 24 crossing points. The are pieces in three different colors. At the start you have to put 2 pieces of each color on the board, so that not two of the same color are adjacent. Each player gets 6 starting pieces.

On a turn you have to put a piece adjecent to one of the same color and then you have to move the adjacten same colored pieces. If there is a piece on the space you have to move to, this piece is beaten. You have to take on of the beaten pieces back.

The player who got rid of all his pieces first is the winner.

In front of the island of Pirate Fishbeard lies the ship of some other pirates. They want to steal the gold from Fishbeard. But the slope of the pirates is so unstable that it can fall over. Each player has to remember how heavy the gold boxes are so that they don't make the slope fall over whenever the pirates transport the gold to their ships!

Children can learn to add up and subtract weights with this game.

A memory game with 4 different ways to play. There are 48 different cards in 6 different colors and different numbers. In one variant you have to find a card in the color roll with a colored die, in another you have to build a sum rolled with a d10.

A memory, bluff racing game. A racing track is built with 24 tiles. The tiles are hidden on the hidden side are values: -3,-2,-1,+1,+2,+3,+4. 
On a game board are 8 other hidden tiles with dice values 1,1,2,2,3,3,4,4.
On your turn you turn over one of the dice tiles and move your pawn the number showing and put the dice tile in another storage. Then take the tile you are landing on and look secretly what is on it. Now you declare what you have seen an move according to what you said. 
If another player does not believe you he can call you bluff and the tile is shown. Whoever is wrong has to move 5 spaces back.
After 8 turns the dice tile sotrage is gone and now we play with the other storage.

40 cards with circles on them divided into 12 parts. Each part is colored in one of the six colors lay on the table.

One of the other 40 cards (exactely the same but a bit larger) is revealed and you have to find the matching cards fastest.

Every player is a street-builder adn tries to build new streets. But every player has also his own spaces he tries not to be overbuild. The players try to overbuild the other players' spaces.

In the game there is normal movement, but also "Amok" movement. If you are in a rush hour you will go amok and now it is easier to build new street in your rampage.

This is a last man standing (means last player with noch overbuilt spaces) game.

This is a biblical cooperative game, where the players try to form new christian societies while traveling through the eastern mediterranean.

When all players are die or imprisoned the game ends and you score how man societies you have build.

Free-download cycling game made in Melbourne (Australia). The pdf provides game board, player tokens, chance cards and shopping cards, and you will need to supply a regular deck of cards from which you will remove the jacks, 3's,and 2's, as well as the jokers.

Players use the cards to move their pieces around the board and collect shopping cards as they fall on green squares. Blue squares are special “chance squares” where players get cards.

There are 2 winners in this game, the person who completes 5 laps first and the person who has the highest value of shopping when they finish 5 laps.

Setup: Charisma can be played on various sized boards. A 6x6x6 or 7x7x7 hex hex board is recommended. Each player has a plentiful amount of their own colored pieces.

Goal: The player with the largest group wins. If tied then another equal or second largest group wins etc...

Turn: Place one of your pieces on the board or strike with one already placed. If you cannot do either then you must pass. Passing is otherwise not permitted.

 Place: 
 one stone anywhere on the board not adjacent to any other stone.
 
 Strike:
 The striking stone moves in a straight line and may not pass through any other stone.
 The strike value must be equal to the number of stones in the target group.
 strike value = number of spaces moved + number of stones in the group(s) adjacent to the departed space.
 Upon striking, the target group is converted to the color of the striking stone.
 




End: when both players consecutively pass or when it’s clear who will have the biggest group.

item.description:
"Battle of Cannae" is the 3rd postcard wargame published by Formosa Force Game in 2011. It simulates the "Battle of Cannae" in 216BC.

Components:
Two players lead 11 Roman units and 7 Carthage units respectively. The battlefield is a 6X9 grids map. There are three kinds of soldiers including cavalry, heavy infantry, and light infantry.

Sequence of play:
Two players do actions alternatively. The Carthage player act first. He need to move all units and then units next to enemy units can attack. In each battle, two players roll 1D6 and add the unit combat value. The difference of the result determine which side needs to retreat or flip the counter. The cavalry unit can move for 3 grids and infantry can move for 1 grid.

Victory condition:
Player who eliminates half of opponent's army win the game immediately.

Overview:
Players are skilled artificers trying to purchase the best components to make the most deadly gladiator weapon the world has ever seen. The game takes place in two rounds. In the first round the players compete in a shrewd auction to get the components they need. In the second round, the players build their weapons and battle to decide the winner.

Components:
1 pack of A-Type Nestoriles (60 tiles in 10 colors)

Easy abstract maze game. Every player start with 4 pawns in one of the four corners. On the board there are lying pieces (shaped like in Blokus).

On your turn you can do both of two actions in the order you like:
1. move one of your pawns as far as you like in an orthogonal direction, blocked by obstacles.
2. move 1 piece as far as you like in orthogonal direction.

The first player having 3 pawn on the nine center spaces wins.

Named after a dutch tv-series.

Every player gets a secret mission (winning condition). It is eleminating another player or taking over a part of the city. One piece of each player (the sniper) can be moved hidden. The rest is roll-and-move.

item.description:
DataMan is an space themed educational game that comes with a "DataMan calculator", 12 cards and 4 dual sided boards. Each of the 12 cards are printed with sepecific instructions that explain how to set up the the "calculator" for differant games. 
The four boards generaly feature a geometric play area as well as instructions for more complicated games.

The DataMan story is generally based around three characters: DataMan, Commander NumberFun and AntiMath. DataMan is a small robot designed by Commander NumberFun who is a ruler of a far away planet. AntiMath is an "Evil wizard from a dark star who has a mysterous power to cloud the minds of his victims and steal away the fun and excitement of mathematics."

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
This game is played on a 12 x 12 field, with some squares colored and some grey. The players have 2 chieftains, 4 druids and 12 warriors each. Each type of pawn has its own movement rules. The goal is to reach the opponent's end zone with two chieftains or warriors. 
The colored squares are either danger fields or trigger fields. If a pawn is on a danger field and the opposing player can move a pawn into the corresponding trigger field, the pawn on the danger field is destroyed.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Fill in the Bleep is the single answer card game that creates a thousand laughs. Players are dealt BLEEP cards and are presented a sentence with a missing word. Players then fill in the blank with their best BLEEP card based on the die roll, (Funniest, Quirkiest, Choice). The dealer will then Fill in the BLEEP with the best submission. But beware of action cards that can change the game in an instant. Be the first to get rid of all of your BLEEP cards and you WIN! Fill in the Bleep will bring brow raising, crazy, zany far out fun.

In Miam, players are merchants who are buying food stuffs at market, then selling them for cash, with more goods of the same type bringing a bigger payout. Whoever has the most money at the end of the game wins.

To set up the game, one player shuffles the 55-card deck – which consists of eleven categories of food (bread, pasta, cheese, etc.) with four cards in each category, four jokers, and seven special action cards – then spreads out the cards face down on the table. Each player starts with five money.

On a turn, a player uses special cards (optional), turns two cards face up, keeps one of these cards while flipping the other face down, sells sets of food cards (optional), and auctions cards on hand to other players (optional). The special cards, which are claimed like any other, allow a player to steal one card from an opponent or keep both cards revealed that turn. When a player sells a set of food cards, she receives 2-16 money for selling 2-5 cards of the same type; these cards are then removed from play. A player can auction any number of cards, with opponents bidding in round-robin fashion for the entire lot.

Once the last card has been claimed from the table, the game lasts three more rounds with players being able to take only the optional actions listed above: using special cards, selling sets, and auctioning cards.

item.description:
Strange cycling board game because during the race the cyclists also switch to air movement (via either a balloon, slow or fast air plane) and travel over water (via a rowing boat, 2 normal boats and a hovercraft) between the tracks. The cyclist who arrives first in the port can choose which boat he chooses and thus move faster over the water to the final cyclist track. So this is a race game over land, air & water. The player who reaches the finish in Chiromo Village wins the game.

From the book The KnowHow Book of Action Games.

name.value: Il Grande Gioco del Giro d'Italia

item.description: Very simple roll & move cycling game published in July 1973. It was based on the Tour of Italy, on the board you start in Belgium , travel through Germany & Switzerland with the final and largest part of the race in Italy. The game comes with four cardboard riders and two dice.

French self-produced cycling game that features a couple of two-faced boards whith which you can make four different tracks, four teams of four riders (some of them hand painted, though monochrome), an extra yellow jersey rider (to replace the leader in stage races), a set of tactic/chance cards, a couple of dice, some markers, a classification sheet and a set of rules.

On your turn you divide your dice throw among the riders, maximum four points per rider; you cannot win the race unles all your riders have reached a certain 'hot' point in the race; you have to play inmediately chance cards but you can keep tactic cards (you take a card for each rider that finishes his move in red fields).

Strange is that the riders also have to pass barriers and gates. The game is played over several stages. In each stage points can be scored depending on your result in that stage. After all stages have been completed the total from all stages is added up to determine the winner.

Be the player who's secret mission card is closest to the mood marker after the character reaches the mood wheel.

Each player is a daemon that guides and influences the main character. The game is a struggle between daemons to control main character's spiritual state or his mood by using the environment surrounding the character. Daemons take turns playing cards to trigger the environment or some of it's aspects to shift the character's mood, advance the character to next section or to change the environment all together. Each player's actions directly affect decisions and strategy of the other players. Game ends when the main character jumps into the mood wheel.

User summary:

This game is part of the Gone Extinct Groovy Tube Book published by innovativeKids. It consists of a hardcover book, a tube of plastic animals, and a game board in the attached box. The book describes various extinct animals, including the plastic animals it comes with, and the game rules are on the last couple pages of the book.

Journey to Extinction Island is a roll-and-move game that has 2-4 players traveling several small paths to collect specimens from each zone (Water, Flyers, Forest and Swamp), while avoiding poachers. The first player to collect one of each type and make it through the final zone (the poacher camp) wins the game.

A Trivial-like game on all facts and history about the soccer team Futbol Club Barcelona, 'Barça'. As in Trivial Pursuit, players advance along the board tracks by correctly answering questions. The first player gathering six trophies will be the winner.

Questions come in six different categories:
- History
- Players, coaches and presidents
- Trivia
- Matches and biography
- Images
- Non-soccer teams

Game components:
- 1 gameboard
- 6 tokens
- 1 die
- 298 question cards, with more than 2,500 questions
- 2 cards
- 36 trophies
- Rulebook

Divine is a game for 2 to 4 players in which you assume the role of a Deity trying to spread their religion in ancient times. You can use your divine powers to quickly gain followers or deviously attack your competing religions. Priests, Zealots, Prophets, and Avatars are your pawns of strategic influence in a developing city which you must control.

The game board consists of 9 tiles that are randomly placed at the beginning of the game to represent an ancient city. Each tile consists of a 36 square grid that depicts various special locations within the city. Players start by controlling a single temple that allows them to train either Priests or Zealots. Priests can preach to gain followers based on the population of each spot on the game board; however, they are vulnerable to be assassinated by an opponent's Zealot. Priests can also establish new temples throughout the city, which can also be desecrated and destroyed by an opponent's Zealot. Unit movement is dictated by multiple dice rolls equal to the number of temples you control.

Players can use divinity cards from their hand to change the outcome of certain scenarios. More powerful units like Prophets and Avatars can only be created by using specific divinity cards. By taking control of special spaces on the board players can also receive additional bonuses.

To win the game players must carefully choose a win condition to work towards. A player wins the game if they are the first to 1) amass 100 follower tokens or 2) capture all 4 tower spaces or 3) be the only remaining player with a temple.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: Simulation of a cycling race. It is possible to play a simulation of a stage race with multiple stages. Typically the length of a stage will vary between 150 and 200 spaces. Movement in the game is determined by the position of the riders in the peloton. A peloton typically consists of 10 teams with each 3 riders.
French board game about indoor cycling, it comes with 3 dice and a board with a metal frame. It is unknown when this game was produced.

Cycling game where the goal is to advance riders depending on the dice rolls (there also is one black die) and on the use of energy cards. There are 5 cyclists numbered from 1 to 5. Each team has one control board where pins can be sticked in. The game is also played with a deck of 200 energy cards, there are 5 different energy cards.
